div.head:
An
Address
div.p:
I offer the following Comedy to the
public, under a circumſtance which has
given my mind the moſt exquiſite uneaſineſs.
On the morning after the firſt repreſentation,
it was obſerved by the papers that there had
been perſons preſent at the Theatre the pre­
ceding evening, who went there determined to
diſapprove at all events. From ſuch a de­
termination it is hard indeed to eſcape! And
the oppoſition intended, was juſtified it ſeems,
by the indecency of ſome of the expreſſions.
—From ſuch a charge I feel it impoſſible to
defend myſelf; for againſt an imputation like
this, even vindication becomes diſgraceful!

As I was not at the Theatre, I ſhould have
had ſome difficulty in underſtanding at what
paſſages the objections were levelled, had not
one of the papers recorded them, with many
cruel remarks. The particulars which were
thus pointed out, will, I truſt, be a ſufficient
apology for themſelves. In the following
pages they are all reſtored; that the public
at large may have the power to adjudge
me, as well as that ſmall part of it, confined
within the walls of a Theatre.

Theſe paſſages have not been reſtored from
any pertinacious opinion of their beauty—
for other expreſſions might have conveyed my
intention as well; but had I allowed one line
to ſtand as altered for the ſtage, what might
not that reprobated line have been ſuppoſed
to expreſs? I ſhrink from the idea! And
therefore moſt ſolemnly aver, that the Comedy,
as now printed, contains every word which
was oppoſed the firſt night, from the ſuſpicion
of indelicacy; hoping their obvious meaning
only will be attended to, without the coarſe
ingenuity of ſtrained explanations; which have
[␣v␣]
have been made, by perſons who ſeem deſirous
to ſurround my talk of dramatic writing, with
as many difficulties as poſſible.

A celebrated Critic, more attended to for
the diſcrimination and learning which appear
in his ſtrictures, than for their lenity; in his
obſervations on the Greybeards, has the fol­
lowing.

p.said:
When Mrs. Cowley gets poſſeſſion of
the ſpirit and turn of a character, ſhe
ſpeaks the language of that character better
than any of her dramatic cotemporaries.

div.p:
This, I confeſs, I hold to be very high
praiſe; and it is to this very praiſe, which
my cotemporaries reſolve I ſhall have no
claim. They will allow me, indeed, to draw
ſtrong character, but it muſt be without
ſpeaking its language. I may give vulgar or
low bred perſons, but they muſt converſe in
a ſtile of elegance. I may deſign the coarſeſt
manners, or the moſt diſguſting folly, but its
expreſſions must not deviate from the line of politeneſs.
[␣vi␣]
politeneſs. Surely it would be as juſt to exact
from the Artiſts who are painting the Gallery
of Shakeſpeare, that they ſhould compleat
their deſigns without the uſe of light and
ſhade.

It cannot be the Poet's mind, which the
public deſire to trace, in dramatic repreſenta­
tion; but the mind of the characters, and
the truth of their colouring. Yet in my caſe
it ſeems reſolved that the point to be con­
ſidered, is not whether that dotard, or that
pretender, or that coquet, would ſo have given
their feelings, but whether Mrs. Cowley
ought ſo to have expreſſed herſelf.

This is a criterion which happily no author
is ſubjected to, but thoſe of the drama.
The Noveliſt may uſe the boldeſt tints;—
ſeizing Nature for her guide, ſhe may dart
through every rank of ſociety, drag forth
not only the accompliſhed, but the ignorant,
the coarſe, and the vulgar-rich; diſplay them
in their ſtrongeſt colours, and ſnatch immor­
tality both for them, and for herſelf! I, on the
[␣vii␣]
the contrary, feel encompaſſed with chains
when I write, which check me in my hap­
pieſt flights, and force me continually to re­
flect, not, whether this is juſt? but, whether
this is ſafe?

Theſe are vain regrets, which I hope my
readers will pardon me, for having a moment
indulged. I now haſten to that part of the
Comedy which will be found in the following
ſheets, as altered for the ſecond repreſentation.

The idea of the buſineſs which concerns
Antonia, Henry, and Gaſper was preſented
to me in an obſolete Comedy; the work of
a poet of the drama, once highly celebrated.
I ſay the idea, for when it is known that in
the original the ſcene lay amongſt traders in
the city of London—and thoſe traders of the
loweſt and moſt deteſtable manners, it will
be conceived at once, that in removing it to
Portugal, and fixing the characters amongſt
the nobility, it was hardly poſſible to carry
with me more than the idea. The circum­
ſtance which moſt particularly intereſted me; 6 and
[␣viii␣]
and fixed itſelf in my mind, was that of
ſnatching a young woman from a hateful
marriage, the moment before that marriage
became valid—that is to ſay, after the cere­
mony. This very circumſtance to which the
Comedy owes its exiſtence, was that, which
ſome of the audience found diſcordant to
their feelings. An event which had in the
laſt century been ſtampt with the higheſt
applauſe, (tho' ſurrounded by many repulſive
circumſtances) was found in this, to be ill­
conceived. I did not, however, diſpute the
deciſion of my Critics,—and the marriage
has been in courſe diſſolved.

The manner in which the Comedy has
ſince been received, gives room to ſuppoſe
that the alteration is approved. It has ſtruggled
with many oppreſſive circumſtances: the
chaſm in the performance, occaſioned by the
repeated illneſs of Mr. Parſons, was ſufficient
to have ſunk it;—but neither that, nor the
ſterile month of December, always againſt
the Theatres, has prevented its being diſ­
tinguiſhed by many brilliant and crouded nights.
[␣ix␣]
nights. I now reſign it to the cloſet, where
without the aid of fine acting, or the faſci­
nations of beauty, and deriving all its little
force from the pen which compoſed it, it
hopes ſtill to amuſe;—the innocent flame of
Seraphina's coquetry may ſtill ſhed rays of
delight on her readers, and the affecting ſitu­
ation of Antonia intereſt them.

lg.l: Prologues, like mirrors, which opticians place,
In their ſhop windows, to reflect each face
That paſſes by—ſtill mark how faſhion varies;
Reflecting Ton in all her wild vagaries:
Point out when hats and caps are large or ſmall,
And regiſter when collars riſe or fall.
Caricature the faſhionable hobby;
And tell if boots or ſhoe-ſtrings grace the lobby:
Nay, bolder grown, have fought for your applauſe,
With many a naughty joke on cork and gauze.
Yet howſoe'er the ſaucy comic muſe
Delights fantaſtic faſhion to abuſe,
From pert Thalia's wit let's try to ſave her,
And ſee what can be ſaid in faſhion's favour.
How many own immortal Handel's ſway,
Since faſhion to the Abbey led the way!
There taking long neglected nature's part,
She hail'd him Shakeſpeare of th' harmonic art.
In vain had warbled Galatea's woe,
If faſhion had not bid the tear to flow.
Hailſtones and fire had ſpent their rage in vain;
You might as well have heard a ſhower of rain.
But now, awaken'd to his magic ſong,
Folks wonder how the deuce they've ſlept ſo long.
His tortur'd airs, all voices made to ſuit,
His choruſſes adapted for a flute.
Hand organ, hurdygurdy, tambourine;
In Handel's praiſe all join the general din.
When Miſs is teiz'd to ſing by every gueſt;
And fond Mamma, too, joining with the reſt,
Cries, Get the new guittar Papa has bought you;

l.said: Play the laſt leſſon Mr. Tweedle taught you.

lg.l: Miſs hems and ſimpers—feigns a cold of courſe;
After the uſual Dear Sir, I'm ſo hoarſe,
Inſtead of a cotillon from her book,
Where favour'd Handel triumphs o'er Malbrouk.
By way of prelude to the charming ſquall,
Thrums like a minuet the March in Saul.
Papa too, who a connoiſſeur now grows,
Accompanies divinely—with his noſe.
Since muſic is ſo univerſal grown,
Shall not our Mourning Bride its influence own?
Sure 'tis the wiſh of ev'ry female breaſt—
That harmony may ſoothe her cares to reſt.
Guided by harmony's enchanting laws,
Her ſweeteſt muſic will be your applauſe.

div.head: Scene, An Apartment at Don Sebaſtian's.
div.stage: Enter two Servants, on oppoſite ſides.

sp.speaker: Pedrillo.
sp.p:
So our Maſter is dreſſing, to dine with Don Gaſ­
per to-day, previous to the wedding ceremony.

sp.speaker: Jaquez.
sp.p:
Yes—Gad the bride will be well
match'd! there's hardly a richer man in Liſbon.

sp.speaker: Pedrillo.
sp.p:
Well married you mean;—as to the
match, you might have made a better, between a
canary bird and a jack-a-lantern. Sixty-five and
eighteen, is a union full as vapoury and unna­
tural.

sp.speaker: Jaquez.
sp.p:
Now you have done it! Prithee who
can that ſtranger be, ſo muffled up, without?

sp.speaker: Pedrillo.
sp.p:
I know not—he takes as much pains
to hide his face, as tho' he had ſtol'n it.

sp.speaker: Jaquez.
sp.p:
Silly!—ſtol'n faces are always ſhewn off
the moſt boldly; witneſs our Ladies, after they
have been robbing the rouge pots. But as to this
ſtranger! he ſays he comes from our Maſter's
friend, Don Henry.

sp.speaker: Pedrillo.
sp.p:
Hah! does he ſo? What that Don
Henry who was obliged to fly, for having fought a
duel?

sp.speaker: Jaquez.
sp.p:
The ſame. Hang me if I'd be playing
at hide-and-ſeek in foreign lands, for drawing a
little blood. I'd go boldly to court, and aſk to
ſpeak to the Queen's Majeſty, and fall upon my
knees, and ſay—

sp.speaker: Pedrillo.
sp.p:
Hiſt; here comes Don Sebaſtian.
Enter Sebaſtian.
Here is a ſtranger waiting without Sir.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Pedrillo.
sp.p:
Truly, Sir, I can't diſcover. I have
queſtion'd and croſs queſtion'd him to no purpoſe
—he's as dexterous at ſhifting an anſwer, as
tho' he was foſter-brother to a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Jaquez.
sp.p:
But he ſays, Sir, he came from Don
Henry,—he who was oblig'd to fly his country for
challenging the—

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Hah! Where is he? going to the wing
No, bring him hither—bring him inſtantly! The
brave unfortunate Don Henry! This hour will
be to him, the heavieſt of his life. he enters
Welcome, Sir! the friend of Don Henry cannot
find a houſe in Portugal, where he would be
more joyfully received.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
What, Sir! dare you thus receive the
friend of a baniſh'd man?—of a man, who were
he ſeen in Liſbon, would have his head claimed
the next hour, by the executioner? If thus you can
receive his friend, how will you receive himſelf?

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
In my arms, and in my heart! I re—
no, I do not rejoice. Oh Don Henry, what im­
prudence! How dare you venture hither before
your pardon has been obtained?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Could you ſuppoſe the intelligence of
Antonia's marriage, would ſuffer me to reſt in any
other ſpot, that the proud ſun viſits? Had I been
beneath the zone from whence he pours his broadeſt
rays, or in the duſky regions of Cimmeria, ſuch
intelligence muſt have impell'd me hither!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
And to what purpoſe? Surely this is a
ſort of Quixotiſm, that muſt end, like the ſub­
lime Knight's contention with the windmills.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
I care not how it ends. The diſpleaſure
of my ſovereign, and my heart torn by the in­
gratitude of the woman on whom it doats—the
ſooner the end approaches, the better!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
I am not now to learn, how hard it is, to
ſtem the torrent of your paſſions—yet if you would
be patient, all might be well.—At leaſt I truſt ſo;
tho' my viſit to England, at that period, prevented
my knowing preciſely the ground of your quarrel.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Quarrel! with contempt Do you then
ſuſpect it was a fray in which I fought; or that
my ſword is drawn in tavern brawls; or to ſup­
port the inſolence, or perfidy of an abandoned
wanton? Duels of that ſort, a ſoldier ſtoops not
to!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Pray then inform—

sp.speaker: Henry.
Sebaſ.
sp.p: I knew him well.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
'Twas he firſt plac'd a ſword upon my
youthful thigh; and drawing forth the burniſh'd
blade, never my Henry, ſaid the hoary general
— never be its luſtre ſtain'd, except to
ſerve your king, or vindicate your friend! Theſe
are the outlines of a ſoldier's duty;—would you
be a perfect ſoldier? Labour to be an exemplary
man!; with that ſword—I thank it! holding
his ſword, and bending over it I puniſh'd his
traducer!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Surely you cannot doubt of pardon.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
But, whilſt I wait for pardon in another
kingdom, my Antonia's loſt—oh!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Is ſhe not already loſt?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
No, ſhe is not—and by heaven ſhe ſhall
not! She's my contracted wife;—no power on
earth can make her another's, whilſt I live.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
All this, my friend, only proves the bit­
ter exceſs of your diſappointment—have you any
ſettled ſcheme?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
I have.—At Madrid it chanc'd that Don
Julio, nephew to old Gaſper my rival, conceived
a warm attachment for me.—From him I learnt
the news of this abhorr'd marriage—the agonies it
threw me in, he compaſſionated; and formed a
ſcheme, which wears a face of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Alas!—it is—well, but pray go on.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Learning that my perſon was unknown
to Don Gaſper, whoſe retired life throws him out
of all public circles, Julio conceived the reſolution
to make me paſs for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
You to paſs for Don Gaſper's nephew—
well!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
With this view he pretended an ardent
deſire to viſit Portugal. His father has in courſe
written to Don Gaſper; we both arrived laſt night,
and Julio has given me the letter, which will fix
me in the houſe of my rival; to prevent, by what­
ever means that may offer themſelves, the deſign
upon my honour—the robbery of my wife!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
My dear unhappy Henry, ſummon your
fortitude whilſt I tell you, that Don Julio's friend­
ſhip, united with your own temerity, cannot ſave
your honour—if your honour is to be wounded
by— ſhaking his head.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
What's that? oh ſpeak Sebaſtian—my
apprehenſions choak me!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
I cannot give ſound to words ſo cruel—
but fly, and ſave that life, which if you are diſ­
covered here, muſt be forfeited.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Hah—I underſtand you—ſhe's married!
ſhe's married! Antonia is another's! Oh, Sebaſ­
tian—let me breathe! throwing himſelf on
Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Courage man! if you would but ſwear a
little now, and give all the ſex, black, brown, and
yellow, to the devil, I ſhould have ſome hopes of
you.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
There's no bearing this! a fine young
fellow yielding himſelf to deſpair, at the very mo­
ment his perfidious miſtreſs is giving herſelf to
another! This very day ſhe weds Don Gaſper.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
This very day ſaid'ſt thou?—oh, ſpeak it
again Sebaſtian—bleſs me with the ſound! is it
this very day?

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Alas! he's mad.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Oh, no; if it be but this day, there yet
are hopes.—

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
She is now in the houſe of your rival.
According to the cuſtom of our country, ſhe this
morning went there, attended by her bride-maids;
and in the evening old Gaſper receives her vows.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
They are mine!—in the face of heaven,
and before witneſſes they are mine;—if ſhe has
given them to another they cannot be valid, but
by my aſſent. I'll fly inſtantly to the houſe—,

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Nay, ſuffer me to attend you; for tho' I
have dear and tender cares of my own, I ſhall
ſcarcely be awake to them, whilſt my friend is in
ſuch danger!

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Oh, Sebaſtian! the bliſs or miſery
of all my years to come, muſt be determined be­
fore the approaching night hath told out half its
hours. The enterprize is difficult—is full of
danger! but what danger can be formidable to a
wretch, who, precipitated on a gulph, muſt leap it,
or be loſt?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſper.
sp.p:
Well Rachel, how is my little
girl? how is the bride? Are her ſpirits got up?
What does ſhe do?—What does ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
Oh lord, Sir, ſhe ſays but little; and
as to doing, a half ſtifled ſigh pops out now and
then, or elſe ſhe's as ſtill as an ivory ſtatute.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Statute! but why don't you talk to
her then, Mrs. Statute; and tell her how happy ſhe
7
ſhe is? You ſhould ſay d'ye ſee ma'am what a fine
houſe you are miſtreſs of?—d'ye ſee ma'am how
many ſervants are at your command?—and this
rich caſket of jewels ma'am, which my maſter pre­
ſents to you—how many ladies will envy you theſe
jewels!—Did not her eyes ſparkle when ſhe found
e'm on her toilet?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
No, Sir; but they glitter'd—for there
was a tear in each.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p: Tear! ay tears of joy, to be ſure!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
The bride-maids and the reſt of the
ladies endeavour'd all they could to divert her,
but to no purpoſe—ſo I up, and ſaid—ſays I,
laws! ma'am, you are the happieſt lady in Portugal.—
My maſter is the moſt aggreeableſt man for an
old—I mean a middle-aged gentleman—that was
the word indeed, Sir! for a middle-aged gentle­
man in all the world. He's never out of temper,
nor peeviſh, except when he has got the gout.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p: Pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
Then ſays I, Ma'am, as to wrinkles—
Lord, what ſignifies minding a few wrinkles?
Why, in forty years, Ma'am, you'll be as wrink­
ley as he is.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
What the devil did you talk to her
of wrinkles for? Wrinkles! to be ſure I have the
crow's feet about my eyes; but many men have
them before they are thirty.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
That's true. Then ſays I, as to my
Maſter's teeth, Ma'am, they are as white, and
even, and poliſh'd—ay, as your Ladyſhip's!
And ſo they are you know, Sir—they have been
home but a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Zounds! Get into the kitchen, and
go near your Lady no more. Was there ever
ſuch a ſtupid chattering—

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
It's nuts to me to ſting him, for I pity
the poor young creature from my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
I don't know whether it is ſtupidity
or archneſs in the wench—I am afraid ſhe means
to laugh at me. Hang me if I would have mar­
ried at all, if my ſon would have married; but
families muſt be kept up; and nothing can per­
ſuade that young dog into the trammels—he'd ra­
ther turn monk than turn to matrimony. Enter
ſervant Well, you ſaw your Lady, honeſt Peter?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Ah—well—well—isn't ſhe a pretty
tight thing? Look in the garden—there ſhe trips
—there ſhe trips.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
With ſubmiſſion, Sir, I wiſh the trip
mayn't have been your's. I am afraid this mar­
riage is one of the falſeſt ſteps your worſhip ever
made.—And here's my young maſter—I am out,
if he does not think ſo too, for all he looks ſo full
of ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
What care I for what your young
maſter thinks, or you either, you old—

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
Joy to you, Sir! joy on this feſtive
morn! but by the way it is very ill dreſs'd for a
bridal morn—the ſame duſky blue it has worn
this fortnight; nor has the ſun been at the expence
of one ray extraordinary! All nature ſhould have
been in gala, on ſuch an event as your nuptials.
—But where is my mother? I came eagerly to
pay my duty.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Mother! Gad it will look odd, to
esee ſuch a ſtrapper as you, call her mother.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p: Shall it be mamma, Sir?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
No. Madam—that's grave and
comely. Madam has a diſtant ſound in it—you
ſhall call her madam. But inſtead of coming du­
tifully to congratulate me Sir, why did you not
dutifully marry yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
Faith, Sir, of all the duties fate has
impoſed upon a man, I think that the hardeſt.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
'Tis an impoſition that ſome hundred
dozen of your great-grandſires, as wiſe and as
witty as your worſhip, have ſubmitted to.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
'Tis deviliſh ſtrange, that it was neceſ­
ſary for ſo many great men to play the fool, to
bring me into exiſtence!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
There's Don Alexis d'Alva has been
half mad to give you his daughter—ever ſince
your return from Italy.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
Ay; had I had the grace to humour
him, Sir, how happy for your fair Antonia! She
might have become at the ſame moment a virgin
bride, and a grandmamma. Drawling.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p: Pſhaw—nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
However, Sir, let her not deſpair—ſhe
may hope for the honour of being a grand-mother
yet. I refuſed the daughter of Don Alexis, with­
out having ſeen her; but now that I have ſeen her,
I think I could venture to exchange my dear
prized liberty, for captivity with her.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Say you ſo my boy? Its the happieſt
news that I have heard. But where could you
ſee her? for Don Alexis is ſo nicely jealous,
that if his ſtone walls had eyes, he'd never ſuffer
either his wife or daughter to unveil before
them.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
I ſaw her at church with her father.
The ſermon was on Chriſtian charity, and to ſhew C how
10
how well ſhe could illuſtrate the doctrine, ſhe lifted
her veil on that ſide next me—for ſhe ſaw me
hungering, and thirſting, for a view.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Memorandum—My wife never goes
to church.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
You ſhock me, Sir—What is my
dear mamma to turn heathen?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
No, Sir—I'll read homilies to her,
and ſhe ſhall have prayers at home.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Don Alexis de Alva, Sir, is come to pay
his compliments to you on your wedding.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p:
'Tis a happy preſage!—Pray recom­
mend my ſuit Sir, and in the mean time I'll go
and aſk bleſſing of the young lady in the garden.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
So my old friend, you're going to do
a wiſe deed to day; Soloman and the child was
nothing to it! Give ye joy—I give ye joy!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
You have a happy knack in your ci­
vilities. You wiſh me joy, as tho' you hoped it
would be ſorrow; and congratulate with an air of
reproach.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
Air of a fiddle-ſtick's end! Why
didn't ye aſk my advice? Could any body have
given ye better? Have I not done the ſame thing
—have I not made an old aſs of myſelf, by mar­
rying a girl?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Never mind that, if your girl does
not transform your aſs-ſhip's ears to horns.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
Ay, that's a bleſſed fear to be
goaded with, in the laſt ſtage of one's mortal jour­ ney!
11
ney! I wiſh the day I left my bed to marry, I
had been confined in it with a gout, an aſthma,
and a dropſy. Oons man, there's no end of your
plagues from this moment!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Pray keep your temper now—keep
your temper. 'Tis a very bad one; but pray keep
it however!

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
Why, you'd find it eaſier to ſpin
cables out of cobwebs; or to pierce thro' the
earth, and ſwim out at the Antipodes, than to
manage a young rantipole wife, and ſo your ſer­
vant—I give ye joy—much good may it do you.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Stay, ſtay, a moment, man! and
tell me which is the greateſt torment, a young
wife, or daughter?

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
Oh lord! why a daughter is a
ſeventh day ague, and a wife is a frenzy fever.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Well, come, I'll recommend ye a
phyſician for your ague.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p: A phyſician—What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Why a lover to take your daugher
off your hands.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p: Who'll be the bold man to do that?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
An impudent young raſcal ſix feet
and a half high; who upon ſuch authority as
huſbands are obliged to take, calls me father; if
you like it, he may call you ſo.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
What Octavio! Will he be my
doctor!—Octavio marry my daughter!—But per­
haps this is a wedding day joke of yours, old
Signor! Gad you'll find this day's work no joke
believe me.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
If its a joke you have it but at
ſecond hand; the original inventor is now in the C2 houſe,
12
houſe, and has juſt deſired me to employ all my
intereſt in his favour.

sp.speaker: Don Alexis.
sp.p:
Intereſt—let him uſe his own in­
tereſt—bid him come. Oh the ſtout rogue!—
Your intereſt! you have no more than a corkcutter
with an archbiſhop. Bid him come, I ſay! I'll
hurry home and prepare my daughter. Ay,
ay, let boys and girls marry, my old friend, but
as for—well I'll ſay no more—much good may it
do ye! Exit.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
By Saint Jeffery the old fellow has
made me feel chilly upon the buſineſs!—What
brought him here to throw cold water upon all my
ardors, and all the pretty little loves that were
ſpringing up, and warming the Lapland region
about my heart. In one's wintry age thoſe gleams
require to be cheriſh'd, and not—Gad I'll go to
little Tony—the baggage has never yet given me
one kiſs; the warm touch of her lips will be an
antidote to his cold poiſon, or I'm—going.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's one Don Julio from Spain.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p: Hey!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Your worſhip's nephew, Sir, from Ma­
drid. He has brought you a letter from his father,
Don Henriques; and deſires you'll admit him to
pay his duty.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Hah! my own ſiſter's ſon—my poor
Olivia's boy, of whom ſhe died in childbed. Let
him come in. Don Henry introduced. My dear
nephew, why I am as glad to ſee thee as if—how
doſt do? Grown up a man! dear, dear, how time
ſlips! 'Twas but yeſterday that your mother came
out of the Convent to be married.—Like her too
13
too—very like her indeed! Well, and how doſt
do Julio? how is thy father?

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Don Henriques was well, Sir, when
I left Madrid—that letter will inform you of his
wiſhes. Scarcely can I contain my feelings! I am
now under the roof with the perfidious Antonia—
and this wretch will call her his wife! Let him be­
ware how he ſhews the ſlighteſt fondneſs! by
heaven if he ſhould—

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Ay, very well—very well. Your
father deſires you may be reciev'd as my gueſt;
and adds, that you are of a remarkable ſober ſeri­
ous turn. I am glad of it Julio—never be wild
my boy! I ſuppoſe you can ſee a pretty woman
without wiſhing her huſband at the devil; or en­
deavouring to perſuade her, that you are a finer
fellow than he is.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p: Thoſe are not my habits, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
I believe ye—there's ſomething in
your look that confirms what you ſay. Well you
are come in happy time—you are going to have
a new aunt—I'll preſent ye to her. But ſhe is
very rigid;—Remember that! ſhe'll expect ye
to treat her with the moſt diſtant reſpect. She's
not ſo young as ſhe looks; no—no—a ſedate
perſon. Some women will look young in ſpite of
years.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
True, Sir; as ſome men will be
fools in ſpite of wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Ay, you are right nephew—'tis a
vile fooliſh age!—Now I'll carry ye to your aunt
—hah, here ſhe comes;—but not ſo pretty a wo­
man I aſſure you, when examined; as at the firſt
glance—ſome women ſtrike at firſt, you know—

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Aſide Hypocritical ſlanderer!
How ſhall I contain my emotions? Antonia enters with
14 with ladies Hah! ſhe doth not look happy—ſome
conſolation to my rack'd heart!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Come deary, cheer up, cheer up!
What all theſe trinkets, and rich laces, and finery,
not brighten ye? Had you married a young fel­
low, he'd have made you no ſuch preſents—his
money would have been laviſh'd on his miſtreſſes
—I'll keep no miſtreſſes; no naughty women ſhall
ſeduce thy nown old man.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
Aſide Nauſeous! Oh Clara, my fate
ſeems to open on me at this moment with a horror
I never yet conceived!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
'Tis a moment too late ſweet couſin!
You have ſubmitted to your fate, think now how
to make your fate ſumbit to you.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
Out, out, no whiſpering till you grow
old enough to turn backbiters! Now call up your
ſmiles patting Antonia's cheek, and your pretty
roguiſh leers! Come ladies your ſpirits, your wit!
I thought every woman was happy on a wedding­
day, whether 'twas her own or her neighbour's.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
The bride's penſiveneſs infects us, Sir.
Mirth ſeems to be impertinent.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
Oh pardon me! Were my ſpirits obe­
dient to my wiſhes, your reproach would have
been undeſerved; but tho' we can determine how
to act, I find we cannot determine how to feel.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Feel, feel! When I was a youngſter,
women had no ſuch word in their vocabulary.
Can't you leave your feelings alone? Never mind
'em; and then like neglected gueſts they'll be in
no hurry to repeat their viſits. I have not re­
garded my feelings many years; and now they
have learnt manners, and don't interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Aſide Not one chance look this way!
15
way! and yet I can forgive the ſweet averted
eye, becauſe it ſpeaks diſguſt to all around her.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
You know the cauſe I have for ſorrow,
and have allowed it; yet my penſiveneſs ought
not to throw a weight upon the day;—I will be
better.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, we ſhall be as happy, and
as faithful as two turtle-doves—ſhan't we, Pet?

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
I hope to prove my duty, Sir. He
never aſk'd my love! aſide.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Ud! I had forgot—here, here's
a nephew of mine—a nephew of yours now; pray
receive him. Don Julio Cavallo.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
aſide Where then is the ſecret
ſympathy of love, which ſhould inſtruct her that
her Henry's near? She ſhall obſerve me.—May
this day be happy to you, lady; and to him, whom
moſt you wiſh to bleſs!

div.stage: She ſtarts at his voice, looks, and ſhrieks.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Heyday little Pet, what ails ye?—
why do you ſtart and ſhriek?—he's my own fleſh
and blood.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
Surprize, Sir. Your nephew ſo much—
he ſo much reſembles—

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Ay, like me, mayhap you think. I
believe there is a family likeneſs, but that need
not have ſcared you ſo.

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p:
No, Sir, it was not that—his reſem­
blance is to—to a moſt belov'd relation, whom
I have loſt.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
Antonia.
sp.p:
Were Don Henry living, I ſhould be­
lieve the ſtranger him; but oh 'tis impoſſible— C4 the
16
the grave will not give back its prey; no, not to
agonizing love!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Come, come, little Pudſey, what d'ye
cry for? your couſin that was drown'd, went to
Mexico to make his fortune, did'nt he?

sp.speaker: Antonia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Well, he got his end there—what
would you have? Come, let us go to the muſic­
room. There you, who have huſbands, will find
them; and you who have none, may make ſnares
for them. Come, Pet! leading her you are al­
ready ſnared; and egad! he muſt look ſharp who
gets you out of my net.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Yes I will look ſharp, and get her
out of thy net, cloſely as thou haſt entangled her.

div.stage: Donna Clara returns, and twitches his arm.

sp.speaker: Donna Clara.
sp.p:
Turn, young man, I pray! he
ſtarts Good Don Julio, tell Don Henry we did
not expect to find him in maſquerade to grace An­
tonia's nuptials.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
I am diſcover'd then—Oh Donna
Clara! your faithleſs couſin.

sp.speaker: Donna Clara.
sp.p: Faithleſs, has ſhe been?

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p: Is ſhe not this day to be married?

sp.speaker: Donna Clara.
sp.p:
Truly I think ſo, Signor, or I am
not a bridemaid; but how far faithleſs I know
not—for I return'd from Arragon laſt night, after
more than a year's abſence. We met but an hour
ſince in the church, nor have we yet had time for
converſation.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Then I entreat you let this diſ­
covery reſt with yourſelf.—It is of the laſt im­
portance to me, that I ſhould not be known to
Don Gaſper; and at preſent, I would be equally
concealed from Antonia.

sp.speaker: Donna Clara.
sp.p:
You muſt give me reaſons for this
requeſt; for I am not certain that I ought not
inſtantly to betray you. It is true, you have been
her lover, but ſhe is now to be the wife of Don
Gaſper;—her duties to him will be of the moſt
ſacred ſort, and ſhe muſt fulfil them ſcrupulouſly.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
Think me not a ſeducer! I have
lov'd Antonia for her purity and virtue; and to
deſtroy her honour, would be to trample on my
own. Oh Clara! few have lov'd as I do. My
paſſion is mingled with the tender protecting af­
fection of a brother; and violation is impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Donna Clara.
sp.p: Pray then tell me—

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
You ſhall know all;—and ſhould
Antonia's marriage be voluntary, I will take no
revenge but to leave her;—but if, as her melan­
choly allows me to hope; ſhe has been deceiv'd
into it, there's not a power on earth that can
divide us.

sp.speaker: Donna Clara.
sp.p:
If your deſign is not contrary to
rectitude, be aſſured I ſhall not oppoſe it. Follow
me to a more diſtant room—a new ſecret is
almoſt as delightful as a new lover.

sp.speaker: Seraphina.
sp.p:
Come along, my charming huſband! Bleſs me,
what eloquence and fire, conſidering you are
fifty-nine! I proteſt, a man thirty years younger
could hardly have found ſuch a variety of things
to have ſaid on ſo trivial a ſubject. One might
miſtake you for an Engliſh ſenator, inſtead of a
Portugueze privy counſellor, you can ſay ſo much
upon nothing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Nothing! what is it nothing that when­
ever I go out of the door, your head is directly
out of the window—like the ſign of Queen Jezebel?
'Tis known to all the impudent young face-hunters
in Liſbon, who ſaunter about my gates, like wolves
before a ſheep-fold—d'ye call that nothing?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Oh no; Heaven forbid I ſhould be ſo
ungrateful towards the grand pleaſure of my life!
Nothing! 'tis every thing—my happineſs! I wait
for ſunſet every day with impatience, becauſe 'tis
known that I then mount my throne—that is,
I enter my balcony, and ſee new proſtrate ſubjects
adoring, and deifying me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Zounds! what a vile cuſtom it was to
build houſes with windows! I'll have them all
block'd up. Sky-lights are the only things for a
Chriſtian country.—Windows and balconies!—
they are fit only for Turkiſh baths, and public
brothels.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Liſten, Deary! and I'll bleſs ye with a
ſecret. Blind your windows, and nail your doors,
but if your honour curtſeying has no better ſe­
curity than theſe, you'll be ſoon in the herd, whoſe
ideal ornaments touching his forehead are ſo
terrific to you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
The devil's in it if ſtone walls won't keep
ye! What ſtronger ſecurity could my honour
have?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
My honour! Rely on that, and I ſwear
to you by every thing ſacred, that no veſtal's life
ſhall be more blameleſs. It is due to my own
feelings to be chaſte—I dont''t condeſcend to think
of yours in the affair. The reſpect I bear myſelf,
makes me neceſſarily preſerve my purity—but
if I am ſuſpected, watch'd, and haunted, I know
not but ſuch torment may weary me out of prin­
ciples, which I have hitherto cheriſh'd as my life.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
If all this is true, what the devil makes ye
ſo fond of admiration?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
I can't tell what devil makes me ſo fond
of admiration; but I know I love admiration, and
I will have it; till he, whom you repreſent, ſays no.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Whom I repreſent! who's that?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Mercy! who can it be, but old, ſhrivell'd,
grey-pated Time? To his negative I ſhall yield—
but with a very ill will, I aſſure you. If the
paſſion we have for admiration is wrong, let nature
look to it—'twas ſhe impreſſ'd it on our hearts; D2 and
20
and it is her law, that to tyrannize over the peace
of man, is to woman conſummation of happineſs!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
And yet you every one of ye pretend
to be tender-hearted, and compaſſionate, and all
that.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Why to ſay truth, one is a ſort of
a paradox. At a tale of woe, I melt like Niobe;
and am agoniz'd at diſtreſs, if I cannot relieve it;
—yet a lover's miſery is delightful! I would not
abate a man who adored me a ſingle ſigh; and
ſhould have no reſt at night, if I thought he was
ſleeping quietly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Lord have mercy! muttering to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Now I hope you feel yourſelf very
much honour'd, that I take you ſo far into my
confidence.—If you have a grain of ſenſe, you'll
be charm'd with it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
I don't know what the devil to make of
ye. Sometimes I think one thing, and ſometimes
another.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Don Octavio, Sir. exit

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Better he, than Ceſar! I'll wait upon
him directly.—Well, I am in the way at laſt,
to have one plague leſs however! Don Octavio is
come to offer himſelf to Viola—Pray ſtep, and
ſend her here to receive him; for I am oblig'd
to go inſtantly to council. I ſhall but juſt ſpeak
to Octavio, and ſend him up;—charge her to re­
ceive him well—ſhe ſhall be married in leſs
than a week. exit.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
I ſhall give his daughter no ſuch charge,
poor girl! How can ſhe receive Octavio well,
with her heart devoted to Sebaſtian? I wonder what
21
what ſort of a thing this Signor is—ſome wrinkled
privy counſellor, like himſelf, I ſuppoſe. 'Tis
very odd now, that thoſe antients ſhould take it
into their venerable noddles, that a youthful bride
is a proper appendage to their dignity; or to
fancy that it requires no more talents to pleaſe a
pretty wife, than to govern a ſtupid nation. Lord!
if my deary would but ſpeak the truth now, and
warn his wiſe brethren—Heyday! is this the
Octavio? Handſome, I vow! young! bold! He
a privy counſellor! Mercy, how could I ſlander
him ſo? Enter Octav. Welcome, Don Octavio!
for I am inform'd that here you muſt have wel­
come. The man I ſaw at church, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
That cruel muſt, checks the tranſport
your welcome gave me! May I not hope that
without a muſt, you would have given me wel­
come?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Oh yes! pray hope it; for as I think
the ſeaſon of hoping, the moſt delightful in our
lives, I ſhould be ſorry to ſhorten yours.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
If you mean to ſhorten my hope by
diſappointment, 'tis kind to protract it; but there
is a way of ending hope, enchanting Viola! with­
out giving deſpair.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Viola, did he call me?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Oh permit me to believe, that the honour
your father allows me, of telling you I adore you,
is not diſpleaſing to you.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Mercy, he takes me for my huſband's
daughter—delightful!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
From the moment I beheld you at veſ­
pers, your image has never left me.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
I vow I won't undeceive him. I take it
very ill of my image, to follow a young man about,
and keep ſuch bad company without my leave.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Whilſt your diſpleaſure is thus playful,
I can ſupport it.—Oh how charming, to find the
information of your face did not deceive me.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Why what did it promiſe you?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Elegance, livelineſs, frankneſs, and un­
derſtanding!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Oh dear! how our ſelf-love operates
on every occaſion. Had I receiv'd you with
frowns, and given you room to believe the com­
mands of Don Alexis unpleaſant to me, you would
have thought me intolerably ſtupid, and wonder'd
why nature gave intelligent eyes to an ideot.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
I will not defend myſelf; to be the
object of your raillery is an enviable diſtinction—
pray go on.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Nay then I have done. An enemy
who won't reſiſt, is not worth combating.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
If you will not combat an unreſiſting
enemy, I hope you will condeſcend to rank him
with your ſlaves.—Conſent to give me your
chains.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Oh, by all means—I like to increaſe my
captives. There! making as though ſhe flung
ſomething over his neck there are my chains—do
you feel them?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Yes, as roſy wreaths—they delight me!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
That's not what I intend. I would
have you ſigh under them—aye, in downright
earneſt too.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
It is impoſſible for me to ſigh in earneſt,
unleſs you tell me the hopes Don Alexis has given
me, make you ſigh in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: What were thoſe hopes, I pray?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
That I ſhould have the tranſporting joy
of calling you mine.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Indeed—I can hardly think it.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
By all the tempting witch'ries of your
face, and the ſoft Cupids in your graceful air, 'tis
true!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
So pretty an oath deſerves a civil reply,
and I therefore proteſt to you, the moment Don
Alexis conſents to my being yours, I'll yield you
my hand without reluctance. But after this frank
engagement, Don Octavio, I expect you to leave
me for the preſent—I have a peculiar reaſon to
requeſt this favour. Some one will come in a
moment, and ſpoil my roguery. aſide

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Your commands ſhall ever govern me;
but when may I again preſume—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
I cannot tell you exactly now—be at
the gate in the evening. Adieu!—adieu!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
At the gate in the evening! How ſweetly
that would ſound, if the little villain had not ma­
trimony in her head. Well, if I muſt be a ſlave
at ſome time in my life, e'en let it be now—a
deſperate action ſhould be done as ſoon as reſolved
on.

div.head: Scene, Don Alexis's Garden.
div.stage:
Sebaſtian and Viola ſeated on a garden chair in
the front. He throws flowers at her, then riſes
haſtily.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
No, I ſwear it Viola—I'll love thee no
more. No more from this inſtant—I am fix'd!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
Coming forward. Won't you indeed?
Let me look in your face, whilſt you make that
wicked oath.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
I could cuff you this inſtant for looking
ſo pretty. Heavens! what a horrible length of time
24
time is before you to do miſchief! Sixteen!—The
fire of thoſe eyes can't be quench'd, nor that ala­
baſter ſkin ſhrivell'd, in leſs than twenty years—
oh, 'tis dreadful!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
You are miſtaken. The ſmall pox may
fret it, the jaudice may tarniſh it—you've many
chances to behold me frightful yet.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Would to heaven ſome of them would
arrive! You to continue ſo lovely, and your father
ſo cruel!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
But ſuppoſe the change ſhould happen
to my father, and he ſhould favour our wiſhes;—
will you then allow me to keep my charms?

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Ay, then indeed—oh, how I would doat
on them! Not one but ſhould have its ſeparate
ſhare of paſſion divided and ſubdivided.—I'd
give to each a twelvemonth, and then begin
again.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
Inventive love! ever the ſame, and yet
for ever new!

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Bleſs me, madam, Don Alexis is return­
ed;—the council is put off—he is aſking for you,
and will be in the garden directly.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
'Tis impoſſible! ſcarcely have I had
time to vent half the malice of my tenderneſs—I
have been here but three minutes.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Three minutes! Oh dear—how every
woman the noon ſide of twenty would rejoice,
if time meaſured out his minutes as love does!
You have been here one hour and a quarter, by
the great dial at the end of the walk.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
Be it hours, or minutes, you muſt leave
me my Sebaſtian—Should my father ſurprize us, I could
25
could expect nothing leſs than ſix months impri­
ſonment in a garret; with the lives of the ſaints
for my ſtudy, and bread and water for my ban­
quet.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Oh, I would embrace the puniſhment, if
at the end of the period, he would allow you to
give me a new impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Now you might as well have put off thoſe
two ſpeeches and a half to the next opportunity
—ſee the conſequence! here comes the old gen­
tleman. Well, I'll not be in the meſs I aſſure ye
—take it all to yourſelves— going.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
Oh ſtay—ſtay, my dear Carlota! he can't
diſcern at this diſtance who we are—let me run
away—I'll go into the houſe thro' the cloſe walk,
and Sebaſtian ſhall ſtay and paſs for your lover;—
it muſt be ſo—the danger will be leſs to you than
me.—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Upon my word—ſo I muſt be the ſcape­
goat! But I won't be blamed I vow—I'll pretend
I don't know you.—'Tis very extraordinary, Sir,
raiſing her voice that the gard'ner could not leave
the wicket open, whilſt he threw out his rubbiſh,
but you muſt throw yourſelf in for more rubbiſh.
—If you don't go this minute, I'll call him to bring
his baſket, and fling you out again with the reſt.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
I deteſt the ſubterfuge, but I muſt ſub­
mit to it.—Oh Carlota, I feel that Viola muſt be
mine!—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
She feels it too.—Ay, pray get you gone,
and don't miſtake your neighbour's gardens again.
—There—there,—that's your way. Going with
him thro' the wing.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Oh you traitreſs—artful ſlut! this muſt
be all a feint. I clearly heard ſhe feels it too!
that ſhe muſt concern my wife, or my daughter—
oh my blood burns!—She feels it too!

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
re-entering I wonder people are not
aſhamed of themſelves, I ſwear, to pretend—Oh,
dear Sir, are you here?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Am I here—cunning gentlewoman! who
was that ſpark, hey? Speak thou powder-puff—
thou ſnip of gauze—thou black pin! Who was
he?—Tell me truth, for I have a touchſtone to
try thee by, that thou canſt not evade.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
I never thought of aſking who he was.
The careleſs gard'ner left the door open—he's
ſome curious ſtranger walking about the ſtreets
of Liſbon.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Ay; ſeeking whom he may devour. But
come—what were the curious ſtranger and you
talking about—What were his parting words?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Aſide. The devil is ſurely prompting
him! Why, Sir, they are not worth repeating,
he was ſaying 'twas—he aſked if it was paſt
twelve o'clock.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Aſide Is it paſt twelve? going a little
off She feels it too! that fits like cuſtard and
cucumber. Thoſe were not the words miſtreſs—
try again! I mean his expreſſion juſt before you
ſaid, pray get ye gone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Oh that, Sir—then he ſaid—what he ſaid
juſt then was—that's a fine poplar! pointing
to a tree.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
AſideA fine poplar, ſhe feels it
too. That does not meet a bit cloſer than t'other.
27
t'other. Come, once more comb-bruſh, recol­
lect! or by St. Anthony—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Now I have it, Sir; I have recollected
now the very words—what the gentleman ſaid at
going away, was—oh, you little black-ey'd
rogue!

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
AſideYou little black-ey'd rogue—
ſhe feels it too! As wide as Liſbon harbour,
from the Iriſh channel. Now by our lady, if
thou doſt perſiſt in giving me the trouble to queſ­
tion thee again, this cane and you ſhall be better
acquainted than your ſkin and your bones, huſſey!
ſhaking her.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Oh how you gripe my arm! devil take
it, if you will have it, hear it then! He ſaid, I
feel that Viola muſt be mine. Bawling. Now
are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
I feel that Viola must be mine—
ſhe feels it too! H—h—h—m!—that fits like
the two ſhells of an oyſter. Aſide. Now minx, I
feel that I have the truth; and I feel a violent
deſire to make you feel this cane. And ſo that
curious ſtranger muſt have been Don Sebaſtian,
whom I have order'd her never to think of—
never—never!—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, ſhe has ordered herſelf never
to think of him: but lord, her thoughts mind her
no more than a conclave of Cardinals would you—
they will gallop towards him in ſpite of her.—

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Will they? but I'll cripple their ſpeed—
they ſhall have a check rein before ſhe's aware.
I'll go this moment, and—oh here madam comes!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Bleſs me Carlota, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Oh dear, why ſhe has been ſo kind to E2 entertain
28
entertain one of your lovers without doors, ma­
dam, whilſt you were engaged with another
within.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
You don't! Come troop miſtreſs to Car­
lota you little black-ey'd rogue!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
To be ſure my father's bewitch'd.
Aſide.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
I'll fit ye! you ſhall pack up your ward­
robe in your pocket handkerchief you little black
ey'd rogue! and beat your march before you are
three hours nearer your wrinkles.—

sp.speaker: Carl.
Alexis.
sp.p:
Well innocent ones, what ſort of enter­
tainment did you give Octavio?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: How did you like him?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what has he got in his head?

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Did you coquet, and give yourſelf only
the allow'd airs on theſe occaſions; or was your
ſtubborn mind ſo full of Sebaſtian, that you gave
him no hopes?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
My dear father, if you'll be pleas'd to
ſpeak in a way that I can underſtand—

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Don't provoke me! What encourage­
ment, I ſay, have you given Don Octavio? have
you dar'd to throw cold water on his hopes? Why
how you ſtand—if you don't anſwer me—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Bleſs me, my dear, what is all this
noiſe?

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Why I can't get her to ſay a word about
Octavio;—I know no more than my ſhoe-ſtring
whether ſhe behav'd decently to him or not.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
To be ſure ſhe did—how can you
queſtion it? But you are really very coarſe; al­
low ſomething to her delicacy!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
I believe they are both beſide them­
ſelves. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Leave her with me—I'll get out all
that paſt—ſhe'll be undiſguis'd to me.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Gad I'll go to Octavio himſelf—that's
the ſhorteſt way. I'll aſk him what paſt—if he is
content, I ſhall be ſo. I'll go to Octavio!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, my dear Viola, this is a
web of my weaving—how I ſhall puzzle thro' it,
I know not. And your poor father—ha, ha, ha,
how you ſtare! be pleas'd to know then that I have
juſt been receiving the moſt violent love in the
name of your ladyſhip—actually perſonating
you!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Perſonating me?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Your father went out this morning,
my dear, and either begg'd, borrow'd, or ſtole a
lover for ye.—The poor youth was introduced to
my apartment—took it for granted that I was
Viola; and begun (as I ſuppoſe he promis'd your
father he would) to adore, and die for me, in
very good form.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
Oh, now the myſtery is clear'd—this is
the Don Octavio—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Yes, yes—now you have the nut—ſhall
we crack it, or throw it away?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
Pray let us get at the kernel. If you
can contrive to keep my father in the dark ſome
little time, it will allow me to concert meaſures with
30
with Don Sebaſtian. You do him the honour to
approve his addreſſes, I know.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Oh, if you can make any thing of the
incident, it is quite at your ſervice. I'll liſten to
Octavio's love-tales with all the condeſcenſion
imaginable; and let him adore me, for a month
to come, if it will be of uſe to you and Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: How very grateful he will be!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Well, let us go then and ſettle matters.
We muſt take Carlota into our council, or the
thing can't go on.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: My father has diſcharged her.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Pho, I'll manage that. It would be
hard, indeed, to marry an old man, and not make
him do as one likes. Young huſbands we are
content to ſubmit to, but when we marry Grey­
beards, it is with the pious deſign to have our
way in every thing.

div.stage: Enter Don Henry, haſtily, followed by Don Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh 'tis too much!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Too much! ay, ſo it is, that they ſhould
be all ſo blind to your ſtarts, your angry bluſhes,
and your ill conceal'd confuſion. I drew you from
the company the moment dinner ended, leſt when
they had done eating they ſhould begin to obſerve.
Do you reflect that Don Philip has only to betray
you to the miniſter, to get rid of his rival for ever?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
It is more than I can bear—the old
dotard's fondneſs, which I dare not yet oppoſe,
diſtracts me! Oh that I could ſpeak to her alone!
—'tis plain amidſt all the bridal gaiety her heart is
not at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Your wiſh is half anſwered, for here
comes her half—the worſt half indeed by forty
years.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Half! thou a lover, and able to ſpeak
thus to a lover? Speak of them as one!

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p:
Forgive me! for faith I am ſo much a
lover at this moment, that I ſcarcely know what I
am ſaying. In a word, I am ſummon'd by my
miſtreſs's maid, who has ſome new information—
in an hour I am again at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Why how now Julio! What ſtole a­
way?—run from the gueſts—hide in corners—
how's this?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
I am not in ſpirits for company, Sir; or
to be ſure this joyful occaſion—

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Not in ſpirits on your uncle's wedding­
day—out upon it!—But tell me boy what do you
think of the bride?—Am I not a happy man—
hey?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: If it turns out ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Oh, I fear no turns. She is virtuous
and modeſt, and you know a modeſt woman is
above all price—but perhaps you do not know
that; for the obſervation is made in a book not
much read now a days.—But what d'ye think
help'd me to get her?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Ay; Sir, what did?—I long to be in­
form'd. Wine perhaps will make him communi­
cative. Aſide.—A ſplendid jointure probably.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Jointure! ſhe minds a jointure no
more than a jointed doll—gueſs again!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I am not fortunate in gueſſing.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Then I'll tell ye—half a ſheet of
paper got her. Ay, you may well ſtare. 'Twas
but half a ſheet of paper—in which I procured it
to be ſaid, that one Don Henry, whom ſhe lov'd,
was ſhrouded and buried—that got her my boy!
ſlapping him on the ſhoulder—there's a contriving
uncle for you!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Poſſible, why I did it—I did it. And
where's the harm? A baniſh'd man is a dead man in
33
in the eye of the law, and a dead man can be no
huſband. He fought a duel and was forced to fly.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
And how, Sir, could you take advan­
tage—

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Why thoſe young raſcals take every
advantage over us, with nature to back 'em; and
we have a right to make repriſals when we can by
the help of art.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
And ſo the lady believed your intel­
ligence?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, ſhe believ'd—and ſwoon'd
—and raved—and took to her bed. Faith the
doctor gave her up; but I ſtill determined when
it came to the laſt gaſp, to tell her the truth, ra­
ther than have her death to anſwer for—but it
never came to that.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
No, no! female grief, tho' ſometimes
obſtinate, is ſeldom fatal. Why, my dear uncle,
you are a perfect Machiavel at a plot. I ſhall
try if I can't out-plot you though. Aſide. It
will be amuſing to ſee Antonia's aſtonishment,
when ſhe finds her Henry is ſtill living—ha, ha—
but then ſhe'll be your's, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Yes, then ſhe'll be mine—ſhe'll be
mine! ha, ha, ha, You muſt know the chit had
no fortune, tho' of a noble family—was peſter'd
with youthful profligate lovers, and at length to
get rid of them, agreed to give herſelf to me—
there's a ſtroke of prudence in a girl!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Aſide. Oh, 'twas more;—I feel it was
a ſtroke of love to me! But what will Don Henry
ſay to this pretty jeſt, which you and I find ſo
laughable?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
What care I what a man ſays a
thouſand miles off.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
But if he obtains his pardon, he'll re­
turn, and then—

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Pardon! Oh, you don't know how
deep I am.—I leave no loop-holes for my ſchemes
to drop through. Hark in your ear—but be ſecret
—I have bought his pardon.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: How, Sir—bought his pardon!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Huſh! that's all under the roſe—
you underſtand me—it coſt me a good lump of
moidores!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
You aſtoniſh me!—Strange kindneſs to
a man whom you could rob of his wife!

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
Kindneſs—tut! I got his pardon for
myſelf, that nobody elſe ſhould have it;—ſo
that if he gets any one to aſk for it, it will be
anſwered, the pardon has been already granted
—but for want of my appearance, he's defunct de­
pend on't;—ay, as much out of the world, as tho'
the ſexton had cover'd him with green-ſod.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
And are you actually in poſſeſſion of his
pardon?

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.p:
As good;—the money is paid, and
I ſhall receive it from the broad-ſeal office to­
morrow.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What a diſcovery is here! Aſide.

div.stage: Don Alexis enters, pulling in Octavio.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Come in here; come into this room, my
dear Octavio! So, here's the young bridegroom.
Now prithee be ſo kind to leave the apartment to
me and Octavio.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Let us not diſturb my father, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Diſturb—a feather! Will you leave us?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, I'll leave ye—but firſt let me pre-
35
preſent my nephew to you. The ſon of my ſiſter
Victoria—you knew her.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Knew her—ay, as well as your noſe does
its ſpectacles. So, young gentleman, what you
are come to dance at your uncle's wedding? and
'twas worth while to come poſt from Madrid on
purpoſe;—you won't cut capers at ſo wiſe a wed­
ding every day, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
Come, come, a truce to your ſneers.
Don't you think he reſembles his poor dear mo­
ther?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Not a bit.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: No! the eyes are the very ſame.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Eyes!—why, her's were blue, and his
are black.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
That's nothing—they've juſt the ſame
look with 'em.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Yes. I grant ye as to the look, his look
as much like eyes as her's did. Then ſhe was
round favour'd.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
What ſignifies that—a long face,
and a ſhort face, may have the ſame air.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But his hair is dark, and her's was light.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
Oons! how you talk—Why all hair muſt
be light, or dark, or ſome colour. Come along,
nephew—When people get old, they grow ſo
obſtinate, there's no convincing them of any thing.
Come along—come along. Exit with Don Henry.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Don't take him to your Antonia, leſt ſhe
ſhould have the odd notion, that he's a fitter bride­
groom for her, than you are. Bawling after him.
Well, my dear boy, I am come on purpoſe to aſk
how you manag'd to-day with my daughter. The
young ſlut is ſo mealy-mouth'd, I could get no­
thing out of her. Was ſhe kind—did ſhe ſhew a
proper ſenſe of the favour?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Senſe of the favour, Sir! She permitted
me to implore the favour of being allow'd to hope.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Well, well, that's the point I would come
to—hang phraſes! Was you contented with your
reception—was ſhe no more than decently coy?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
She was all goodneſs, Sir. Why what
an old fellow's this! aſide

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
All goodneſs—well, that's in generals.
Tell me—come now tell me honeſtly, did ſhe
let you kiſs her?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Heavens! I dared not let ſuch a thought
exiſt. Had any man but her father aſk'd me—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
You'd have ſaid yes;—you would, I know
you would! Boaſted of the ſweetneſs of her lip,
and of the preſſure of her white hand, but I—
I muſt know nothing—I am an old father.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
aſide What can be the meaning of all
this? Is it his ſuſpicion, or his folly?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Come, why won't you tell me now?—
Tell me at once.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What ſhall I tell you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
What!—why that ſhe treated ye kindly—
that you liked her pouting lips; and that—

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Believe me, Sir, I dared not attempt
ſuch a liberty.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No! why had you not my permiſſion?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
I did not ſo conſider it, Sir; but if
you'll lay your commands on the lady, when I
have the honour to wait on her again—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Ay, that I will, never fear me. But
pray where's the foundation of your great content,
if nothing kind paſt? I fear the ſlut has deceiv'd
him. aſide

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Kind! ſhe was all angelic ſweetneſs,
Sir!

sp.speaker: Alex.
Octav.
sp.p: She had the condeſcenſion to promise—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What—what?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
That when you ſhould order her to
beſtow her hand on me, ſhe would obey you with­
out reluctance.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: She promis'd that, did ſhe?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
She did; and my delighted ſoul hath
dwelt on the ſound from that moment.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Well, well, come again this evening, and
your ſoul ſhall have ſomething elſe beſides ſound
to dwell upon, or I'll underſtand why.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Good Sir, you would be very conveni­
ent I perceive, but it unfortunately happens, that
I chuſe the ſweet trouble of getting over my love
difficulties myſelf.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Oh, to be ſure—above being oblig'd I
ſee! but I tell you theſe young baggages have all
their arts to make a man half mad, and I know
'em—I'll manage her my little Octy; never fear!
Sound indeed!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Allow me, Sir, with all humility, to re­
queſt that you'll give yourſelf no trouble in the
buſiness. S'death! If I don't take care I ſhan't
have the pleaſure of running down my own game.
If you wiſh to make a ſon-in-law of me, Sir, you
muſt permit me to travel the road of love in my
own manner.—No bearing him!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Zounds! what a heat you're in! Why,
ſo you may travel the road of love in your own
manner—I only mean humbly to open the turn­
pike gates for ye.—See what one gets by one's
good nature! Exit.

div.head: Scene. Don Gaſper's Garden.

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p:
looking; as tho' uncertain. Surely
'tis herſelf—yes, 'tis Antonia! Like the ſoft lilly
preſs'd by the dewy robe of night, ſhe bends her
lovely head. Oh Clara! lead her—lead her to her
Henry! Hah—accordant to my wiſh they come!
But how may I be maſter of her thoughts? Per­
haps to her friend, ſhe will unveil her inmoſt heart.
I'll ſeem to ſleep—yes; but whilſt I appear to
ſlumber, my ear will hang on every ſound ſhe ut­
ters, and my whole ſoul be ſuſpended on her­
breath. He reclines on a bank. Some ſhrubs pre­
vent his being immediately ſeen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
This is the ſtrangeſt whim! ſeeking ſhades
and ſolitude, inſtead of company and mirth,
What will Don Gaſper ſay?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Oh name him not; the arrival of the
young ſtranger his nephew, has renewed all my
miſeries. But here my ſorrows have a ſhort ceſ­
ſation. Oh, how thoſe lonely ſhades will ſooth
my ſadneſs! Each day I'll ſeek the ſoft receſs, and
opening all the treaſures of remembrance, live on
my Henry's image.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Come, come, that's a ſort of image wor­
ſhip we don't allow. It would be more catholic
to live in lonely ſhades with himſelf. This ſoft
receſs would be at leaſt more poetical my dear,
with a handſome young man in it, even tho' he
ſhould be uncivilly aſleep. pointing to Henry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Not regarding her. Oh, I'll call back
each ſacred hour which bleſt our wedded ſouls;
trace each fond ſcene that chaſten'd love made
pure, and in the dear review, forget that I'm a
wretch.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Ay, do forget it pray, and look behind
thoſe ſhrubs—there's a youth as much like Don
Henry, as ever one impudent rogue was like
another.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Hah! 'tis Don Julio—let us retire before
he wakes. And yet—Oh Clara! I could wiſh his
ſleep lengthen'd to eternity; and myſelf immor­
tal, to ſtand thus and gaze on him!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
One might almoſt fancy it Don Henry
himſelf; only unhappily 'tis not the cuſtom for
people to leave their family manſions in the church­
yard, to repoſe on violets for their miſtreſſes to
gaze on them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
The reſemblance is ſtronger now he ſleeps.
When awake, this ſtranger has a ſcorn—a ſeverity
in his eye—ſomething that made me fear; but
Henry's eye talk'd only love! Oh, I have ſeen a
volume in a ſingle glance;—one look has ſaid,
what eloquence and learning might try to imitate
in vain.

lg.l: Sweet roſy ſleep! Oh do not fly,
Bind thy ſoft fillet on his eye,
That o'er each grace my own may rove,
And feaſt my hapleſs, joyleſs love!
For when he lifts thoſe ſhading lids,
His chilling glance ſuch bliſs forbids—
Then roſy ſleep oh do not fly,
But bind thy fillet on his eye!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
I ſay on the contrary open your eyes!
Who knows but they may by this time have ac­
quired a ſofter expreſſion?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Fie, Clara! let us go this inſtant—you
will ſurely wake him. going haſtily.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Starting up. Yes, he is awakened in­
deed! Oh my Antonia, turn! Turn ſweet traitreſs,
and look upon the man you've injured!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Shrieking. Oh, I ſhall ſink! What art
thou? Is Henry then alive in Julio? Oh tell me
whilſt I yet can breathe—Say, art thou both, or
nothing?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Convince thyſelf. Embracing her. Oh,
my Antonia!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
No! 'tis not air—my arms return not
empty to my boſom, but meet a ſolid treaſure!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: A treaſure you have lightly priz'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Alas, my Henry, I believ'd thee dead!
Oh let me touch thee yet again! taking his hand
Theſe veins are warm with life! health bluſhes
on thy cheeks; and this ſoft preſſure darts thro'
my nerves, and is new life to me. Oh my Henry!
it is—it is thyſelf!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Can this joy be real? You thought me
dead, Antonia, and choſe in bridal pomp to
celebrate my obſequies!—The Epheſian ſtory
will be always new.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Think not my heart perfidious. Had
I choſe a youthful huſband, you might have
term'd me fickle—but from thoſe I fled—abhorr'd
a ſecond love, and fix'd where venerable age
ſecured my heart from every tender impulſe. A
guardian 'twas I aſk'd, and not a huſband.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Nature made women falſe, to ſee how
well they would excuſe their crimes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
'Tis well you treat me thus, to check the
tranſport of beholding thee; which elſe might be
too much! But think, reproachful man! conſider
my high birth; and ſlender fortunes—Behold me
a lonely orphan, haunted by a train of lovers—
ſome too high in rank to make them fear to act,
what'er their wiſhes prompted. 'Twas to eſcape
all theſe—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Oh, was it that indeed, which forced
thee to this marriage?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It cannot be a marriage ſince my Henry
lives! My vows were given to thee—the ſolemn
contract ſign'd; and heaven, by its holy prieſt,
invoked to bleſs the engagement!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And in heaven 'tis recorded!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I do acknowledge it: and death alone
could give Antonia right to make herſelf another's.
Baſe artifice deceiv'd me, and virtuous art muſt
free me from the deceiver.—But, oh, thy life's
at ſtake! Where ſhall we fly?—At what bleſt
altar ſolemnize our vows?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Wilt thou then follow my ſad fortunes?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Yes—to the utmoſt boundaries of the
earth!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Oh, my ſick ſoul needed a cordial of
this mighty ſtrength to cheer it! Know then,
Antonia, we need not fly—my pardon's promis'd
—I have important ſecrets to communicate—
to-morrow thou'lt be mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To-morrow!

sp.speaker: Henry.
Ant.
sp.p:
Thus then! kneeling and hear me, hea­
ven!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And thus I liſten to thee. kneeling

div.stage: Enter Don Philip, followed by Alexis.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Tony! my little Tony, where art? Hey!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
'Sblood! what's all this?—Ah—didn't I
warn ye of the bride's odd notions?—didn't I
warn ye?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: We are undone!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Truſt to me. apart Thus then I invoke
the ſacred powers to witneſs my reſolve—Never
to know another love! never to hold myſelf bound
by any vows, but thoſe made to the lord of my
affections, the contracted huſband of my heart!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Her contracted huſband—mark that
now. to Alexis

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
And thus do I invoke the ſame gracious
powers, to bleſs you, as you're true; and to pre­
ſerve thee and that huſband in a ſweet eternity
of love! —Don Philip runs to help them up.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Thank ye, my dear children! There—
there, what d'ye ſay now to my choice? Had ever
man ſuch a wife, and ſuch a nephew?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
No faith, I believe not; and may I be
hanged if I believe it now, though I have ſeen it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Envy—ſheer envy! You ſee when I
marry a girl, I know how to chuſe one. Come
along, my pigeons. going off with one under each
arm.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Hark ye, Don Julio—give me a minute.
twitching him back Come, I know there's ſome
jeſt in this. You muſt truſt me; and egad if you
will. I'll—do truſt me, I know 'tis ſome jeſt.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I admire your penetration.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
I love a jeſt to my ſoul, and gad if you'll
truſt me—here—here's a ſeal ring taking it off
'twas worn by my great grandfather fifteen gene­ 5 rations
43
rations back. I value it beyond the great ruby in
the throne at Delhi.—Egad I have a great mind
to give it ye. Putting it on again, and throwing
his hand behind him.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
An idea darts upon me!—yes, by heaven
it ſhall be done! this is the critical inſtant of
Antonia's fate. Aſide. A ring valued by you
ſo highly, Don Alexis, ought to grace no finger
but your own—I refuſe to accept it; but if you'll
entruſt it to me, I ſwear when you next ſee it you
ſhall know the jeſt.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: Shall I indeed?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Yes—and I'll venture to promiſe that
you ſhall enjoy it too!

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
There's my ring. I pant for the hour
of its being reſtored, as much as a girl does to
unburthen her firſt love ſecret.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
I too pant for the hour; for if I miſtake
not, I ſhall mean time make ſuch a uſe of your
great grandfather's ſeal ring, as muſt make that
and every future hour bliſsful to me!

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
What can he mean to do with it? that
ſeal ring make all his future hours bliſsful! May
be there's ſome conceal'd witchcraft in it, and he
has had wit enough to find it out; or if rightly
turn'd it may make a man inviſible, or ſomething
of that ſort—there have been ſuch things former­
ly—Gad I'll follow him tho'—if my ring has any
properties of that kind, how ſnugly I ſhall be
able to watch my wife!

sp.speaker: Seraphina.
sp.p: It is in vain, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Charming Viola, why are ye ſo barba­
rous? Is it not by your own permiſſion I attend
you?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Yes, I know it is; but what of that?
When the ſun ſhone I liked you, and now by
candle light I hate you—do go, I will not be
teazed.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: This is ſo ſingular!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
What, that a woman ſhould change her
mind ſince morning? You, I ſuppoſe, are ſo
wonderfully conſtant, that you change your's only
with the moon.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Do not ſuſpect me of fickleneſs—permit
me to prove my conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Impoſſible—impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
I ſee I muſt tell you, to avoid alterca­
tion. Be pleaſed to know then, Sir, that there
is nothing on earth I deteſt like this ſober, quiet, prudent
45
prudent method of loving. Your vows have a
father's approbation;—you are expected;—you
enter the houſe without difficulty;—you yawn
through an hour of common-place;—the wed­
ding-day is fixed, and we go to church to be mar­
ried, in the ſame hum-drum ſtupid way, that mil­
lions of dull couples have done before us. No,
no, this I can't ſubmit to, believe me!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Ah, 'tis plain we were born for each
other, we think ſo exactly alike! aſide. Theſe
I confeſs are misfortunes; but how in our caſe
are they to be avoided?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
If you are really in earneſt in your
love, you muſt contrive to make Don Alexis hate
you. Let him throw a thouſand difficulties in the
way, and then I'll throw myſelf—into your arms!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Oh, that extatic promiſe! But your
father is unhappily attach'd to our marriage—What
the devil can I do to make him ſet his face againſt
it? I fear it is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Poor Don Octavio! then you have no
hopes—for I do ſwear by every thing that can
bind me, whilſt Don Alexis approves of our
nuptials, I never will be your's.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
I'll bribe fellows to ſlander me! was ever
ſo unhappy a dilemma? I thought his approbation
till this moment a bleſſing; but now I would will­
ingly make him ſhut his doors againſt me, and
confine you to a grated room, with a dozen ſmoak­
dried Duennas to guard you.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Ay, then indeed things would go on
gloriouſly! You would be ſighing and groaning
without, and I should be weeping and wailing
within. Then for plots and contrivances—then
for bribes and ſcaling ladders—then for eſcapes and
46
and purſuits—Oh, what would I not do for a man
who ſhould bring me into ſuch bliſsful difficulties!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
I ſwear you ſhall be obey'd, whatever I
hazard. Who knows but an elopement may
finiſh the affair ſhort of marriage! Aſide. A
buſtle without—the door opens a little, and diſcovers
Carlota ſtruggling to keep out Alexis.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
I tell you, Mrs. Brazen, I will be
amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Bleſs me, Sir, how can you be ſo bar­
barous to diſturb the young people?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
There's Don Alexis! now begin your
talk directly—prevent his coming in; if he ent­
ters, I never will be your's.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: Let me in I ſay.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Sir, you muſt not come in.
Going to the door.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Muſt not come in—why you young
dog! Well, well, tell me then, is ſhe kind—
hey my little Octy! is ſhe kind?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Not quite ſo kind as I wiſh her to be.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Oh, a jade! You ſlut you—you per­
verſe baggage! I will have you kind to Octavio.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Devil take him, why does he not bid her
diſmiſs me? then ſhe'd fly to my boſom. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p:
Octy! Octy! ſtruggling with Carlota
have you kiſs'd her yet?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: No! loud—in paſſion.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Then you ſhall—I will ſee you kiſs her,
by Jove!

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Lord Sir! How can you be ſo rum­
buſterous?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Come in, I will.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: aſide Then go out I muſt.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: So! what's ſhe off! burſting in.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Off! yes, and now I'll be off. What
woman of delicacy could bear to be thus treated?
Or what father but you—going.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Now dear Octy do not be angry—do not
be angry! You have the character of one of the
civileſt, politeſt, diſcreeteſt—

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
The character lies, Sir—I am none of
theſe. I am rude, ill-natured, unjuſt, fickle, and
full of extravagance!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Hey day! Why I believe you are full of
wine too.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
I am every thing you ought to dread.
You could not in all Liſbon have picked out ſo
hopeleſs a huſband for your daughter.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Oh Lord! no—you are a very hopeful
young gentleman—The character you have given
of yourſelf, would ſuit ye all I doubt;—but you
ſeem ſo intimate with your faults, that like a ſtale
acquaintance, they'll ſoon diſguſt ye—therefore
fickle, drunk, or mad, my daughter ſhall be
your wife.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Are you ſo obſtinate Sir!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay—and if ſhe dares demur—

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Oh I am ruin'd—if you perſist I am
ruin'd. Dear Don Alexis pardon me! I ſee my
ſcheme was ridiculous—a better ſtrikes me. In
one word—ſtay, let's take care we are not heard—
in one word, you and I muſt both be in a plot,
againſt your lovely capricious daughter.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Her vivacity renders a ſtupid, formal,
allow'd courtſhip, intolerable to her. If you
perſiſt in countenancing my addreſſes ſhe will
hate me; but if you order her to ſee me no more,
and allow me to ſteal her out of a window, or over
48
over the garden wall, ſhe'll be the happieſt bride
in Portugal.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
D'ye ſay ſo? Oh a perverſe baggage—
but I'll fit her! Won't love ye, merely becauſe
I order her to do it! that ſhe had from her
mother!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
You muſt conceal your knowledge of
that.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Pho! d'ye imagine I don't ſee your whole
drift now? If you was to continue talking a
Lapland winter, you could not make the hint
clearer. Gad ſhe's coming, and my wife with
her! So d'ye hear you Signor Don Octavio,
ſpeaking loud you are—I ſay you are—you ſhall
know what you are another time; for the preſent
that's your way, Sir, that your way out; and I'll
be ſworn you ſhall never know the way in. Puſhing
him out.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
Why my dear huſband, is ſo mere a
gudgeon—there's no credit in deceiving him.
Now remember your leſſon. to Viola

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: So miſtreſs—I have diſpatch'd your lover.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Have you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
A young rakeſhame! your not liking
him proves you have your father's penetration.
Notwithſtanding his modeſt front, there's not
ſuch a deſperate fellow this ſide the Ganges; no
nor 'tother ſide the Black Sea.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
My ſweet love, are you ſpeaking of
Don Octavio?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Yes, I am. Take care you give him no
encouragement, d'ye hear girl? No whiſperings
from your balcony; no private correſpondences; no
49
no billets dropt by your officious maid, on pre­
tence they are meant for ſome carotty-pated
country couſin!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Dear Sir!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
No pencil'd aſſignations on the back of
your fan; or cards in lemon juice—to be call'd
on detection ſecret orders to your perfumer, for
pearl powder, and bloom of Circaſſia.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
How can you put ſuch things in the
girl's head, deary?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
aſide That her fingers may put them
in practice, to be ſure; but you are not up to me
there, deary! aſide.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p:
But a few minutes ſince, you were fear­
ful, Sir, that he was not received with ſufficient
favour.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
That was—that—well, no matter. That
